Image Processing

Parameter Set
.


Description
..

A convienent way to exploit the KneeLut for basic image processing tasks is given by the parameter set for Image Processing. All transformations apply to the given configuration of the KneeLut in the following order:

  1. Offset Correction, range [-1.0, +1.0], identity 0
  2. Gain Correction, range ]-inf, +inf[, identity 1.0
  3. Gamma Correction, range ]0, +inf[, identity 1.0
  4. Invert, identity 'off'

Mathematically, without invert:

p' = ( gain * (p + offset) )1/gamma

with invert:

p' = 1 - ( gain * (p + offset) )1/gamma

Since all these corrections can be configured to the identity, there is no explicit switch to turn the Image Processing on or off, they are always applied to the active configuration loaded into the KneeLut.

Definitions:
max = 255 for 8bit/pixel, max = 1023 for 10 bit / pixel, max = 4095 for 12 bit per pixel
P : pixel value
p : normalized pixel value p = P / max
p' : normalized pixel value after the image processing transformation
P' : pixel value after image processing transformation P = p' * max


Parameters
.

Offset

Range [-1.0, +1.0], identity 0.

The Offset is a relative value added to each pixel, which leads to a behaviour similar to a brightness controller.

A relative Offset means, the e. g. 0.5 adds half of the total bightness to each pixel. In absolute numbers when using 8bit/pixel, 128 is added to each pixel (0.5 x 255 = 127.5), for 10bit/pixel 512 (0.5 x 1023 = 511.5). If you rather want to add an absulte value to each pixel do the following calculation: e. g. add -8 to 8bit/pixel offset = -8 / 255 = -0.031372549...

Gain (for gray feature)
Red Gain, Green Gain, Blue Gain (for color feature only)

Range ]-inf, +inf[, identity 1.0.

The Gain is multiplicatice coefficient applied to each pixel, which leads to a behavior similar to a contrast controller.

For the color feature a separate gain can be given for each color component, which can be used for whitebalancing.

Gamma

Range ]0, +inf[, identity 1.0.

The Gamma correction is a power-law transformation applied to each pixel, which tries to ballance the nonlinear response of a CRT monitor. Normalized pixel values p ranging [0, 1.0] transform like p' = p^(1/gamma).

Invert

Identity 'off'.

When Invert is set to 'On', the output is the negative of the input. Normalized pixel values p ranging [0, 1.0] transftom to p' = 1 - p.
